title: Cornelius Jakhelln
text:
Cornelius Jakhelln (born 31 August 1977 in <a href="Kristiansand">Kristiansand</a>), also known as Cornelius von Jackhelln, is a Norwegian vocalist, guitarist, musician, writer and poet.
Biography.
Musician.
Born in <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a> but currently residing in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, Cornelius was 18 years old when he and <a href="Lars%20Nedland">Lars "Lazare" Nedland</a> formed the <a href="avant-garde%20metal">avant-garde metal</a> band, <a href="Solefald">Solefald</a>. Along with being a lead vocalist, guitarist, bassist and composer in the band, he also handles the vast majority of lyric writing for the band. <a href="Solefald">Solefald</a> has since released one demo and seven full-length albums. In December 2005, the band was nominated for the Norwegian <a href="Alarm%20award">Alarm award</a> for best <a href="heavy%20metal%20music">metal</a> album for the album, "".
Cornelius' first time recording with a band other than <a href="Solefald">Solefald</a> was in July 1999, when Cornelius performed guest vocals for the <a href="gothic%20metal">gothic metal</a> band <a href="Monumentum">Monumentum</a> for the songs "Black And Violet", a cover of the Italian band <a href="Death%20SS">Death SS</a>, and "The Colour of Compassion". These recordings were released in 2004 on the Monumentum compilation album, <a href="Metastasi">Metastasi</a>.
In 2003, Jakhelln began working on a new band. The name chosen was <a href="Sturmgeist">Sturmgeist</a>, and the band plays an experimental style of <a href="black%20metal">black</a>/<a href="thrash%20metal">thrash metal</a> with lyrics sung in English, <a href="Norwegian%20language">Norwegian</a>, and German about <a href="Germanic%20mythology">Germanic mythology</a>, war, and recitations of <a href="Goethe">Goethe</a> poetry. On January 24, 2005, Sturmgeist released their first full-length, entitled <a href="Meister%20Mephisto">Meister Mephisto</a> on the record label, <a href="Season%20of%20Mist">Season of Mist</a>. Since then, Sturmgeist has gone on a small European tour, and had recruited two more official members, John "Panzer" Jacobsen on guitar, and Christian "Anti Christian" Svendsen on drums, ending the band's time as a solo project. Sturmgeist's second full-length, entitled "<a href="%C3%9Cber%20%28album%29">Über</a>", was released October 16, 2006 through <a href="Season%20of%20Mist">Season of Mist</a>. His third album released under the Sturmgeist name was released in 2009, entitled <a href="Manifesto%20Futurista">Manifesto Futurista</a>.
On August 26, 2005, Cornelius also announced on his official website that he would finally be recording an <a href="electronica">electronica</a> album in <a href="Sofia%2C%20Bulgaria">Sofia, Bulgaria</a> that he had been planning for six years. He has described the project as a combination of <a href="electronica">electronica</a>, <a href="darkwave">darkwave</a>, <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a>, <a href="drum%20and%20bass">drum'n'bass</a> and <a href="black%20metal">black metal</a>.
The album, entitled <a href="My%20Only%20Drug%20Is%20Madness">My Only Drug Is Madness</a> was released in 2007, under the band G.U.T, meaning Grace Under Torture. He got the phrase from a <a href="Thomas%20Mann">Thomas Mann</a> short story entitled <a href="Der%20Tod%20in%20Venedig">Der Tod in Venedig</a>.
Writer.
Aside from being a musician, Cornelius made his debut as a writer in 2001. He has had many writings published in newspapers and magazines and a tetralogy of poems entitled <a href="Quadra%20Natura">Quadra Natura</a> for which he was deemed the winner of a national Scandinavian novel writing contest in 2007. The third volume of this four-book collection, entitled <a href="Fagernorn.%20Quadra%20Natura%200111">Fagernorn. Quadra Natura 0111</a> was released on March 16, 2006. He is also involved with a Paris-based literary review entitled <a href="Avant-poste">Avant-poste</a>, which was nominated for the French CNOUS annual award, as one out of ten cultural projects. He is also writing the <a href="libretto">libretto</a> for a contemporary opera telling a story from the <a href="paganism">pagan</a> times of the North.
He has continued to have a successful career as an author and was quoted in an interview stating "Being a writer is my job. And my music is… It's like a "Nebenjob", as you would say in Germany. A passion."
Education.
Cornelius has a master's degree in philosophie/lettres modernes from <a href="Paris-Sorbonne%20University">University of Paris IV: Paris-Sorbonne</a> and a master's degree in the philosophy of <a href="cognitive%20science">cognitive science</a> with a minor in aesthetics from the <a href="University%20of%20Sussex">University of Sussex</a>. He is currently pursuing a PhD in philosophy and cognitive science from <a href="%C3%89cole%20des%20hautes%20%C3%A9tudes%20en%20sciences%20sociales">École des hautes études en sciences sociales</a> and a PhD in philosophy from the <a href="University%20of%20Oslo">University of Oslo</a>.
